results.response: I recommend the clip titled "Elora Hardy — building from bamboo is beautiful" (speaker: Elora Hardy), cited in the transcript of "TED's secret to great public speaking." Key idea: using bamboo as a building technology can improve people's lives by providing a locally available, strong, elegant and safer form of housing — as Elora Hardy says, "It is growing all around us, it's strong, it's elegant, it's earthquake-resistant." This quote from the provided transcript supports the claim that the technology (bamboo construction) makes living conditions better.

results.name: recommendation
results.response:
I recommend talk_id=29968 — "The most important thing you can do to fight climate change: talk about it."

Justification from the retrieved TED data:
- The speaker gives concrete, everyday actions people can take: she cites “simple solutions that save us money and reduce our carbon footprint at the same time. Yes, light bulbs. I love my plug-in car. I'd like some solar shingles.” (context [1]).
- She lists lifestyle choices people can adopt: “eating local, eating lower down the food chain and reducing food waste, which at the global scale, is one of the most important things that we can do to fix this problem.” (context [1]).
- She also models practical behavioral changes to reduce personal emissions (e.g., minimizing travel, using video): “The biggest part of my personal carbon footprint is my travel... I usually don't go anywhere unless I have a critical mass of invitations... and I've transitioned nearly three-quarters of the talks I give to video.” (context [1]).
- In addition, the talk explains how to talk about climate with others by connecting to shared values so individuals can influence their communities — “start from the heart... begin by talking about why it matters to us, to begin with genuinely shared values.” (context [2]).

These excerpts show this talk combines clear, actionable daily-life tips with guidance on how to engage others — matching your request for a talk about climate change and what individuals can do.

results.name: precise_fact
results.response:
Talk: "Listening to shame" — Speaker: Dr. Brown.

Evidence from the provided TED transcript: Dr. Brown frames shame and vulnerability as obstacles people get "paralyzed" by and argues for overcoming them — e.g., "you cannot talk about race without talking about privilege. And when people start talking about privilege, they get paralyzed by shame" and later, "vulnerability is not weakness" and "vulnerability is the birthplace of innovation, creativity and change." She also notes TED as "the failure conference" — "very few people here are afraid to fail" — all of which show the talk addresses moving past fear/shame and anxiety.

results.name: key_idea_summary
results.response:
Talk: "Are droids taking our jobs?" (talk_id=1574)

Short summary — key idea: The speaker argues that technology can and does improve people’s lives, including for the poorest. As the transcript notes, "the bottom of the pyramid is benefiting hugely from technology," illustrated by Robert Jensen’s study in Kerala where mobile phones made "prices stabilized... waste was not reduced — it was eliminated. And the lives of both the buyers and the sellers in these villages measurably improved."

results.response: I recommend the talk "Averting the climate crisis." It explicitly addresses everyday actions people can take — the talk asks "Now, what can you do?" and lists concrete steps: "Reduce emissions in your home... Insulation, better design. Buy green electricity... buy a hybrid. Use light rail. ... Be a green consumer. You have choices with everything you buy" (transcript). Those lines show it focuses on practical, daily-life choices individuals can make to lower their carbon footprint.

results.name: key_idea_summary
results.response:
Title: Are droids taking our jobs?

Summary of key idea (based on the provided transcript): The speaker argues that technology improves people's lives—especially for the poor—by making markets and innovation more inclusive and efficient. For example, he cites Robert Jensen's study showing that when fishing villages in Kerala got mobile phones, “prices stabilized…waste was not reduced — it was eliminated. And the lives of both the buyers and the sellers in these villages measurably improved.” He also notes that “the work of innovation is becoming more open, more inclusive, more transparent and more merit-based,” so digital tools both raise welfare at the bottom of the pyramid and broaden who can contribute ideas.

results.name: recommendation
results.response:
I recommend: "The most important thing you can do to fight climate change: talk about it" — Katharine Hayhoe.

Justification from the retrieved TED content:
- The talk both urges everyday people to act and gives concrete daily-life steps: Hayhoe lists "simple solutions that save us money and reduce our carbon footprint at the same time. Yes, light bulbs. I love my plug-in car. ... Lifestyle choices: eating local, eating lower down the food chain and reducing food waste" and even practical habits like a switch to turn off everything when you leave the house and minimizing travel by grouping speaking engagements (context [1]).
- Beyond actions, the talk focuses on the most accessible individual contribution: conversation. As the transcript states, "The number one thing we can do is the exact thing that we're not doing: talk about it" and she explains how to "start from the heart" by connecting climate to shared values so people will engage (contexts [14], [2]).
- Because it pairs specific daily actions with guidance on how to motivate others (talking in ways that connect to values), this talk directly addresses "what individuals can do in their daily lives."

results.name: key_idea_summary
results.response:
Title: Are droids taking our jobs?

Summary of key idea (from the provided transcript): The speaker argues that technology — especially digital tools and mobile phones — is improving people's lives, including those at the “bottom of the pyramid.” As evidence, he cites economist Robert Jensen’s study of Kerala fishing villages, where “when they got mobile phones for the very first time… Prices stabilized, so people could plan their economic lives. Waste was not reduced — it was eliminated. And the lives of both the buyers and the sellers in these villages measurably improved.” He also emphasizes that “economies run on ideas” and that technological innovation is becoming “more open, more inclusive, more transparent and more merit-based,” which further benefits people globally.

results.name: recommendation
results.response:
I recommend "The most important thing you can do to fight climate change: talk about it" by Katharine Hayhoe.

Justification from the retrieved TED content:
- Hayhoe pairs communication with practical, everyday personal actions: she explicitly lists "simple solutions that save us money and reduce our carbon footprint at the same time. Yes, light bulbs. I love my plug-in car. I'd like some solar shingles" and imagines "a switch beside the front door, that when you left the house, you could turn off everything except your fridge" ([1]).  
- She also recommends lifestyle choices people can adopt: "eating local, eating lower down the food chain and reducing food waste" ([1]).  
- She models individual behavior change with her own choices: "The biggest part of my personal carbon footprint is my travel... I carefully collect my invitations... and I've transitioned nearly three-quarters of the talks I give to video" ([1]).  
- And she emphasizes the power of ordinary people talking about climate: "The number one thing we can do is the exact thing that we're not doing: talk about it" ([14]/[19]).

These passages show the talk addresses both how individuals can change daily habits and how personal conversation/action helps drive larger change.
